userestrict.head: Publication Rights/ Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Before publishing quotations or excerpts from any materials, permission must be obtained from the Special Collections Librarian/ Associate Curator of Rare Books and Manuscripts, and the holder of the copyright, if not the Rockefeller Library at Colonial Williamsburg.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Edmund Jenings' Letter to [William Blathwayt], 1716 May 25, Manuscript # 1987.4, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Library, Colonial Williamsburg Foundation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: Jenings describes changes in the appearance of Williamsburg since he last visited. The town is "much inlarged {sic} and {has} a prospect for being a useful Town...The inhabitants living more decent after the English manner & in the Country plentifull {sic} & in Peace." Jenings refers to the dispute between Auditor General {Phillip Ludwell} and Governor {Alexander Spotswood} and offers himself as a replacement for Ludwell should Blathwayt desire him. Written from Ripon Hall, York County (Va.).
